citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Female Shiba Inu (tattoo #98) has poor dental health. There is thick hard brown tartar covering all of the cheek teeth and
most of the surface of canine and front teeth. The gums are thickened where they contact those teeth.
Male Poodle (tattoo #22) The 2 lower middle front teeth are loose and move easily when touched.
Poor dental health can cause pain and discomfort to the animal as well as lead to further health issues. The licensee is
required to use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee is
required to have the above mentioned dogs evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to
establish an effective treatment plan. The licensee must ensure that all dogs receive adequate veterinary care at all times

During the inspection, two adult dogs were identified as under medical treatment but there were no records of medications
or diet modification being given to the dogs. The facility representative states the treatments are being done but have not
written them down.
*Bulldog (tattoo #56) was prescribed Ofloxacin eye drops to be given twice daily for 1 week on 10-March-2023.
*Bulldog (tattoo #40) was prescribed oral Cephalexin once a day for 10 days for a skin condition. Additionally, this dog is
being fed puppy food and karo syrup daily per an approved protocol for weight management.
Failure to keep medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving
adequate veterinary care.
Dealers must keep copies of medical records that include if a problem is identified (such as diseases, injury, or illness),
the date and the description of the problem, examination findings (if any), test results, plan for treatment and care, and
treatment procedures performed. The licensee must ensure that all procedures and treatments performed on the dogs
including any medical treatments being provided to each dog are documented on a complete medical record containing all
required information.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
William Janecke, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Female Shiba Inu (tattoo #98) has poor dental health. There is thick hard brown tartar covering all of the cheek teeth and 
most of the surface of canine and front teeth.  The gums are thickened where they contact those teeth.  
 
Male Poodle (tattoo #22)  The 2 lower middle front teeth are loose and move easily when touched. 
 
Poor dental health can cause pain and discomfort to the animal as well as lead to further health issues. The licensee is 
required to use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee is 
required to have the above mentioned dogs evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to 
establish an effective treatment plan. The licensee must ensure that all dogs receive adequate veterinary care at all times 
3.13(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
During the inspection, two adult dogs were identified as under medical treatment but there were no records of medications 
or diet modification being given to the dogs. The facility representative states the treatments are being done but have not 
written them down. 
*Bulldog (tattoo #56) was prescribed Ofloxacin eye drops to be given twice daily for 1 week on 10-March-2023.

*Bulldog (tattoo #40) was prescribed oral Cephalexin once a day for 10 days for a skin condition. Additionally, this dog is 
being fed puppy food and karo syrup daily per an approved protocol for weight management.  
Failure to keep medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving 
adequate veterinary care. 
 
Dealers must keep copies of medical records that include if a problem is identified (such as diseases, injury, or illness), 
the date and the description of the problem, examination findings (if any), test results, plan for treatment and care, and 
treatment procedures performed. The licensee must ensure that all procedures and treatments performed on the dogs 
including any medical treatments being provided to each dog are documented on a complete medical record containing all 
required information. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
William Janecke, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
